Willis waiting for his moments on deep Kentucky team

Bullitt East's Derek Willis stays ready for his moments to help Kentucky basketball

Willis waiting for his moments on deep Kentucky team

Kyle Tucker, ktucker@courier-journal.com 3:36 p.m. EST December 11, 2014

Kentucky forward Derek Willis, center, contests a shot by Montana State forward Terrell Brown in the second half. The University of Kentucky Men's Basketball team hosted Montana State University, Sunday, Nov. 23, 2014 at Rupp Arena in Lexington. Photo by Jonathan Palmer, Special to the CJ(Photo: Jonathan Palmer)

11 CONNECT 25 TWEETLINKEDIN 4 COMMENTEMAILMORE

LEXINGTON, Ky. Dominique Hawkins admitted it earlier in the week, following his brief escape from the bench to play in place of an injured Tyler Ulis, and Derek Willis said the same thing Wednesday night after breaking a sweat for the first time in two weeks: It's hard to be the 11th and 12th men on the top-ranked University of Kentucky basketball team.

"You go from playing your whole life, starting your whole life, and now you're on one of the most unbelievable teams ever made," Willis said. "It can get frustrating, but if you just have this mindset of 'get your opportunities,' you just play off that."

MORE: UK survives tough test against Columbia

Willis, a 6-foot-9 sophomore from Bullitt East High School who has 3-point range and explosive leaping ability, would play major minutes for most other teams. But most don't have 10 projected NBA draft picks like the Wildcats do. Even with two platoons to spread the playing time, Willis and Hawkins are the odd men out, barring injury.

Ulis' injury gave Hawkins a chance Sunday against Eastern Kentucky, and he produced six assists. Devin Booker's injury UK has not specified either player's ailment, but he wore a brace on his right knee in the second half against EKU opened the door for Willis on Wednesday night against Columbia. Likewise, he delivered.

Having played just two total minutes in the Cats' previous three games, he gave them five points in nine minutes against the Lions. That was a key contribution in a tighter-than-expected game. Willis' offensive rebound and subsequent free throws gave UK its first lead with 13:18 remaining and his late 3-pointer put a Columbia comeback out of reach.

Kentucky coach John Calipari talks about his team's slow start and eventual victory over Columbia in Rupp Arena

"It's like having an NBA mentality," said Willis, who'd previously played just 32 total minutes, scored only 14 points and sat out four of the first nine games completely. "The dudes in the NBA that don't play, they're still there before the game, working out an hour before, and then after the game they put another hour in. If you have the mentality of, 'Whenever my opportunity comes up,' you're just always ready."

Willis proved he could contribute this summer in the Bahamas. Forward Trey Lyles and center Willie Cauley-Stein were both out with injuries then, so Willis had a spot on UK's second platoon and produced an average of six points and 3.5 rebounds in 17.8 minutes through six exhibition games against foreign professional teams.

Then Cauley-Stein and Lyles returned, the season started and Willis vanished until he was needed Wednesday night.

"I was proud of Derek Willis," coach John Calipari said. "Defensively active, played with confidence. There's just a couple things that he's got to do in the zone to post the ball, but I thought Derek was outstanding."

And if Booker can't go Saturday against No. 21 North Carolina, Calipari Willis will be the oversized two-guard on the Cats' second platoon against the Tar Heels. The coach said if Booker and Ulis could not practice Thursday, they will not play.

"Anything can happen," Willis said. "So I'm just staying ready."

    Last SlideNext Slide

    While it hasn't been easy, he said he is genuinely happy for his teammates who play more minutes and they're thrilled for him when he gets his moments to shine.

    "I don't know what's out in the media or whatever, but everyone's a good kid. We have no problems with each other. Everyone wants to see each other succeed," he said. "I want everybody to do well, and if that means me not playing then fine."

    That is Kentucky's unusual luxury, to have stashed on the end of the bench a 6-9 former top-100 recruit who had scholarship offers from Indiana, Louisville and Purdue, not complaining about his situation but waiting on his chance.

    "Derek's a great player," guard Aaron Harrison said. "He's probably underrated, obviously, on our team. But Derek is a great player. We all have confidence in Derek. We know he can play."
